Graphical abstract The graphene-supported SnP nanosheets are prepared as a dual-functional accelerator towards Li2S n (n=1, 2, 4, 6, 8) conversion for long-life Li-S batteries. To anchor the polysulfide and enhance the conversion kinetics of polysulfide to disulfide / sulfide is critical for improving the performance of lithium-sulfur battery. For this purpose, the graphene-supported tin (IV) phosphate (Sn(HPO4)2·H2O, SnP) composites (SnP-G) are employed as the novel sulfur hosts in this work. When compared to the graphene-sulfur and carbon–sulfur composites, the SnP-G-sulfur composites exhibit much better cycling performance at 1.0C over 800cycles. Meanwhile, the pouch cell fabricated with the SnP-G-sulfur cathodes also exhibits excellent performance with an initial capacity of 1266.6 mAh g−1 (S) and capacity retention of 76.9% after 100cycles at 0.1C. The adsorption tests, density functional theory (DFT) calculations in combination with physical characterizations and electrochemical measurements provide insights into the mechanism of capture-accelerated conversion mechanism of polysulfide at the surface of SnP. DFT calculations indicate that the Li-O bond formed between Li atom (from Li2S n , n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) and O atom (from PO3-OH in SnP) is the main reason for the strong interactions between Li2S n and SnP. As a result, SnP can effectively restrain the shuttle effect and improving the cycling performance of Li-S cell. In addition, by employing the climbing-image nudged elastic band (ci-NEB) methods, the energy barrier for lithium sulfide decomposition (charging reaction) on SnP is proved to decrease significantly compared to that on graphene. It can be concluded that SnP is an effective sulfur hosts acting as dual-functional accelerators for the conversion reactions of polysulfide to sulfide (discharging reaction) as well as polysulfide to sulfur (charging reaction). Keywords Lithium-sulfur battery Tin (IV) phosphate Dual-functional accelerator Sulfur host Density functional theory calculations 1 Introduction The increasing demands for portable electronics, electric vehicles and large-scale smart power grid propel the research and development of high specific energy power supply devices beyond Li-ion batteries [1]. Li-S batteries (LSBs) have attracted growing focus to meet the emerging requirement owing to the high theoretical specific energy around 2600 Wh kg−1 and the low cost of elemental sulfur [2–4]. Although offering these advantages, the practical applications of LSBs have been hindered by some critical challenges, such as the insulating nature of both sulfur and lithium sulfide, the volume expansion and shrinking of the cathode during discharge and charge, the shuttle effects caused by the soluble intermediate lithium polysulfides (Li2S n , n = 4, 6, 8) in the ether electrolyte and the sluggish conversion kinetics of Li2S n (n = 4, 6, 8) to Li2S2 and Li2S [5–7]. The above-mentioned issues cause the loss of active species, low coulombic efficiency, corrosion of lithium anode and poor cycling performance of the Li-S cell [8–10]. In order to restrain the shuttle effect, significant efforts have been done by synthesizing new materials and designing novel architectures for cathodes. Among these works, various porous carbon materials, such as hollow carbon spheres [11], graphene [12,13], carbon nanotubes [14], have been widely employed as the electronic conductor and efficient framework materials for physical confinement towards Li2S n (n = 4, 6, 8). However, the non-polar carbon surface only possesses weak affinity towards the polar Li2S n clusters via physical van der Waals (vdW), and results in the limited restriction of Li2S n shuttling [15]. Given this, the polar materials with strong electrostatic attractions, chemical absorptions, chemical interactions and catalytic activities toward Li2S n have been introduced into sulfur cathodes to trap them via different mechanisms. Wu et al. reported that the soluble polysulfide anions were strongly adsorbed by the surface cations of vermiculite via the electrical double layer effects, hence protecting polysulfide from dissolution [16]. The silver-polyoxometalate clusters were employed to construct a sulfur electrode due to its dual-functional Louis acidic and basic sites towards Li2S n , and improving the cycling stability of the cathode obviously [17]. It has been demonstrated that the compounds which can form Li-X (nonmetal atoms in hosts, such as S, O, N, P) bonds or S-M (metal atoms in hosts, such as Ni, Co) bonds with polysulfide are the effective anchors for polysulfide and accelerators for its conversion reactions. In this fields, metal sulfides (CoS2 [18,19] and MoS2 [20]), metal oxides (MnO2 [21] and Fe2O3 [22]), metal nitrides (MoN [23] and WN [24]), metal phosphides (CoP [25] and MoP [26]), montmorillonite [27], and NiFe layered double hydroxides@nitrogen-doped graphene [28] were employed to fabricate sulfur cathodes and improve the electrochemical performances and lifespan of Li-S cells significantly. The α-metal phosphate, a kind of layered tetravalent metal phosphate compounds with the general formula of M(HPO4)2·H2O (denoted as MP, M = Zr, Sn, Ti, etc.) have the advantages of stable layered structure, thermal and chemical stabilities [29]. Guan et al. synthesized the 2D sandwich‐like α‐ZrP/polypyrrole (α‐ZrP/PPy) material as the sulfur host for LSBs. It is found that the layered α‐ZrP nanosheets not only anchor the polysulfide strongly, but also accelerate the conversion of polysulfide to Li2S [30]. The layered tetravalent metal phosphates also show considerable interlayer d spacing of 7.5 Å, much larger than 3.4 Å of graphite [31]. Due to the large interlamellar distance, the layered tetravalent metal phosphates were also confirmed to be benefit for improvement of Li ion transfer in the materials and demonstrated as the anode materials for Li-ion batteries [32,33]. Herein, Sn(HPO4)2·H2O (denoted as SnP) and graphene-supported SnP (SnP-G) composite were synthesized and served as the sulfur hosts to anchor polysulfide and accelerate the kinetics for conversion reactions. By combining XPS tests and DFT calculations, the strong interactions between SnP and Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) were revealed to be derived from the van der Waals force and chemical bonds between the Li atoms (from Li2S n , n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) and O atoms (from SnP). Moreover, DFT calculations also demonstrate that the activation energy for the insoluble Li2S decomposition to polysulfide is also dramatically reduced on the surface of SnP. The cyclic voltammetry measurements and symmetrical cell tests further experimentally prove the conversions of polysulfide to Li2S (discharging reaction) and polysulfide to sulfur (charging reaction) are both significantly propelled by SnP. This work puts new lights on the fundamental understandings of the catalytic properties of the layered metal phosphate in Li-S batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation Tin (IV) phosphate (denoted as SnP) was synthesized by the hydrothermal method as reported previously [34]. Phosphoric acid (H3PO4, AR, 85%) and tin (IV) chloride pentahydrate (SnCl4·5H2O) with the molar ratio of 2:1 were dissolved uniformly in 30 mL distilled water. And then the mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and reacted at 180 °C for 24 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the white precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with deionized water for three times, and then maintained in an oven overnight at 60 °C to yield white powders. SnP-G composites were prepared by mechanical milling the as-prepared SnP and graphene (Purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech Co., Ltd) for 2 h with a mass ratio of 3:7. The sulfur was loaded by traditional melt-diffusion method. The as-prepared SnP-G and sublimed sulfur with a weight ratio of 2:3 were grinded and mixed in a mortar, followed by sealing in glass bottle and heating at 155 °C for 12 h under argon atmosphere in an electric-tube furnace. The final products were denoted as SnP-G-S. The control sample denoted as G-S was prepared using the same procedure as above-mentioned without SnP compound. 2.2 Material characterization The morphologies of the samples were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a JSM-7800F, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a JEM-2100 microscopy, and EDX on a JEOL 2100F system, respectively. The crystal structures of the samples were detected by X-ray diffraction diffractometer (XRD) on X’pert Pro diffractometer (50 kV, 50 mA) with a Cu Kα radiation. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was detected by Nicolet iS50 (thermofisher scientific). Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of the samples were measured at 77 K with a surface area analyzer (Autosorb iQ2). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on Escalab 250xi system to analyze chemical compositions and valence states of the atoms in material close to the surface. 2.3 Adsorption test The absorption behaviors of graphene and SnP towards polysulfide were tested by putting them in Li2S6 solution. The solution containing 10 mmol L-1 Li2S6 was prepared according to the previous report [35] by mixing 1 mmol Li2S and 5 mmol sublimed sulfur in 100 mL mix solvent of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxymethane (DME) (volume ratio 1:1) under continuous stirring for 24 h in an argon-filled glove. Afterwards, the graphene and the SnP compounds of equal mass were added into the as-prepared Li2S6 solution, respectively, followed by vigorous stirring. The experiments were conducted in an Ar-filled glove box. After absorption, the precipitates denoted as G-Li2S6 (graphene in Li2S6 solution) and SnP-Li2S6 (SnP in Li2S6 solution) were collected and dried in the vacuum transfer bin of the glove box for further XPS and XRD tests. 2.4 Symmetrical cell fabrication and electrochemical measurements The symmetrical cells were fabricated with two same electrodes as the working electrode and the counter electrode, respectively. The electrodes employed in the symmetrical cells were fabricated by preparing the slurry containing SnP-G composites and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder in weight ratio of 4:1 mixed in the solvent of N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) and coating the as-prepared slurry onto the aluminum foil, followed by vacuum-dried at 60 °C overnight. The graphene electrodes were prepared with the same method as mentioned above but to replace SnP with graphene. The electrolyte used in the symmetrical cells was prepared by mixing 1 mmol Li2S and 5 mmol sublimed sulfur in 100 mL electrolyte containing 1.0 mol L− 1 lithium bis-(trifluoromethane) sulfonamide (LiTFSI) in mix solvent of DOL and DME (volume ratio 1:1). 30 μL of the as-prepared electrolyte was added into each coin cell. The electrolyte without Li2S6 was served as the blank control. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were conducted on a PARSTAT 2000 electrochemical measurement system. CV curves were measured and recorded in the potential range of −1.0–+1.0 V at a scan rate of 5.0 mV s−1. EIS measurements were carried out in the frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with amplitude of 5.0 mV. 2.5 Li-S cell fabrication and electrochemical measurements The sulfur cathodes were prepared by mixing the active materials, acetylene black (AB) and PVDF binder with a mass ratio of 8:1:1. Subsequently, the mixture was grinded to prepare the slurry in NMP and casted onto the aluminum foil using the doctor blade. The obtained electrodes were vacuum dried at 55 °C for 12 h. The areal sulfur loading was about 1.2 mg cm−2. CR 2016 type coin cells were assembled in argon-fill glove using the as-prepared sulfur cathode, lithium foil anode in thickness of 400 μm, the electrolyte containing 1.0 mol L−1 LiTFSI and 0.2 mol L−1 LiNO3 in mix solvent of DOL and DME (volume ratio 1:1), and separator of Celgard 2500. The amount of electrolyte in the coin cell was about 25 μL. Li-S pouch-type batteries were fabricated by using 8 pieces of the as-prepared SnP-G-S cathode and 9 pieces of lithium foil anode in thickness of 100 μm. The size for both cathode and anode is 3 × 4 cm2. The cathodes and anodes were cross stacked using the Celgard 2500 as separator followed by injection of the electrolyte and packed by Al-plastic film. The areal loading of sulfur was about 3.0 mg cm−2, and the amount of electrolyte was about 0.96 mL in the pouch cell. The galvanostatic discharge–charge measurements were conducted at room temperature in voltage range of 1.7–2.8 V on a battery test instrument (LAND CT-2001A, China) at different rates (1.0 C = 1675 mAh g−1 based on the mass of sulfur). CV curves were measured on PARSTAT MC between 1.7 and 2.8 V at scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. EIS analysis was conducted on a PARSTAT 2000 electrochemical measurement system with amplitude of 5.0 mV in the frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz. 2.6 Computational methods All adsorption energies (ΔE ADS) presented here were calculated by DFT calculations using Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) with revised Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (rPBE) exchange–correlation functional and the projected augmented wave (PAW). The plane–wave cutoff energy was 500 eV for all system. We used the periodic slab simulation and all data from SnP (002), and the unit cells of SnP were modeled by a 2 × 2 unit cell. One-layer slab which contains 4 Sn atoms for SnP was carried out in the calculation and neighboring slabs were separated by 20 Å vacuum. The adsorbate and one-layer slab were allowed to fully relax during whole optimization. The Brillouin zone was sampled with a 2 × 2 × 2 Gamma-centered k-points grid for all adsorbates (Li2S n , n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) and 2 × 2 × 1 girds for SnP. The adsorption energy was calculated using the most stable adsorption configuration and it suggested the strength of the binding between the adsorbed species and the surface of SnP. The ΔE ADS can be represented by the Eq. (1): (1) Δ E ADS = E TOT - E SLAB - E ADS Here, E TOT is the energy of adsorbed system, E SLAB is the energy of the clean substrate surface and E ADS denotes the energy of the adsorbates. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the material The illustration of the synthesis procedure of the cathode materials is shown in Scheme 1 . The white SnP precipitates were obtained after the hydrothermal treatment of aqueous H3PO4 and SnCl4 solution. The morphologies and microstructures of the as-prepared SnP powders were observed and recorded by SEM and TEM. As can be seen from Fig. 1 (a), the primary nanosheets of SnP in size of around 200 nm aggregate seriously. The TEM images (Fig. 1(b)) indicate that the SnP is consisted of the uniform hexagonal nanosheets in size of around 200 nm with a certain extent of stack. The corresponding elemental mapping in Fig. 1(c) exhibits the distributions of Sn, P and O element along the hexagonal nanosheets. The XRD pattern of SnP as shown in Fig. 1(d) is well consistent with the cubic SnP (JCPDS: 31–1397), depicting that SnP is well crystallized with high purity. The peak at 11.46° corresponding to the (002) lattice plane shows an interlayer spacing of 0.76 nm which confirms the layered structure of SnP [36,37]. Besides, the FT-IR spectrum for SnP is shown in Fig. 1(e). The peak above 3000 cm−1 is attributed to the free surface –OH symmetrical stretching band of P-OH group, and the peak at 1620 cm−1 is due to the bending vibration of H2O. The broad peak in the region of 1000–1300 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration of PO3 [38]. These peaks are well consistent with the FT-IR spectrum of SnP reported in the previous literature [39]. The above mentioned results indicate that the SnP synthesized by the hydrothermal method exhibits good crystal structure and regular morphology. However, as illustrated in Fig. 1(f) for N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of SnP, the SnP exhibits a low specific surface area of around 45 m2 g−1 due to the serious aggregation. Therefore, the SnP-G composites were further prepared, in which the graphene can provide the large surface area and excellent electron conductivity, as well as the SnP can be effectively dispersed at graphene surface. The SEM images and elemental mapping of SnP-G composites are shown in Fig. 2 (a). It can be observed that the SnP particles disperse separately and homogeneously at the surface of graphene. The distributions of element Sn, P and O are also homogeneously (Fig. 2(b)). From the TEM images of SnP-G composite (Fig. 2(c)), the SnP particles in size of about 200 nm are also found to distribute separately and homogeneously on the surface of graphene. The elemental mapping of the composite (Fig. 2(d)) also confirms the evenly distribution of the elements of Sn, P, O and C. The XRD pattern of SnP-G (Fig. 3 (a)) also shows the typical diffraction peaks of SnP (JCPDS: 31–1397), which locate at 11.46°, 21.08°, 25.88°, and 36.32° corresponding to the (002), (110), (112) and (020) lattice plane, respectively. Therefore, it can be concluded that the SnP-G composite with homogeneous elemental distribution is successfully prepared by employing the mechanical milling method. For the SnP-G-S composite, the distinct orthorhombic structure of S8 (JCPDs: 08–0247) can be observed from the XRD patterns as shown in Fig. 3(a). The sulfur distribution and the elements Sn, P and O dispersions are all homogeneous on the surface of graphene as shown in Fig. 3(b). Therefore, the sulfur cathode materials are successfully prepared by heating the SnP-G composite with sulfur. The pristine yellow–brown Li2S6 solution was prepared according to the previously report [35]. In order to explore the absorption capability of SnP towards polysulfide, the as-prepared SnP particles were added into the pristine Li2S6 solution. After two hours, the yellow–brown solution containing Li2S6 became colorless and transparent (Fig. S1, supplementary material) indicating the dissolved Li2S6 was effectively absorbed by SnP. In contrast, after the addition of the same amount of graphene into the Li2S6 solution, no obvious color change can be observed which suggests the weak interaction between graphene and polysulfide. This phenomenon demonstrates that the as-prepared SnP exhibits strong absorption towards polysulfide. XPS was applied to analyze the valence states of the atoms in SnP and SnP-Li2S6 powders. The high-resolution Li 1s spectrum of SnP-Li2S6 shows a single peak at 55.0 eV in Fig. 4 (a), which displays a 0.8 eV shift to the lower binding energy compared with the Li 1s spectrum of the pristine Li2S6. Fig. 4(b) presents the high-resolution Sn 3d spectra of the pristine SnP and SnP-Li2S6 powders, in which the peaks at 495.8 eV and 487.3 eV can be assigned to Sn 3d 5/2 and Sn 3d 3/2, respectively, indicating the valence state of Sn is +4 in SnP [40]. Notably, the Sn 3d 5/2 and Sn 3d 3/2 of the SnP-Li2S6 both shift to the lower binding energy of 495.6 eV and 487.1 eV, respectively. This phenomenon reveals the increased electron density at the metal center of Sn [41,42]. The high-resolution S 2p spectra of the pristine Li2S6 and SnP-Li2S6 are shown in Fig. 4(c). The peaks at 163.1 eV and 161.6 eV for the pristine Li2S6 are corresponding to S B 0 for the bridge sulfur and S T −1 for the terminal sulfur, respectively [43,44]. Compared with the pristine Li2S6, the binding energy of S B 0 and S T −1 for the SnP-Li2S6 shifts 0.4 eV and 0.2 eV positively, respectively. The above-mentioned results about the peak shifts in S 2p, Sn 3d and Li 1 s attest the chemical interactions between SnP and Li2S6. Besides, as shown in Fig. 4(d), the XRD pattern of SnP-Li2S6 shows no significant difference compared with that of the pristine SnP which demonstrates the stable crystal structure of SnP even after treating with lithium polysulfides. The interactions between Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) and the optimized SnP (002) lattice plane are further investigated by DFT calculations. The atomic structure of SnP, the adsorption configurations and the adsorption energies for Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) on the surface of graphene and SnP are shown in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5(a) presents the atomic structure of SnP, in which each Sn atom coordinates with six oxygen atoms from totally six PO3 groups, and each PO3 group coordinates with three different Sn atoms via three oxygen atoms [45]. As shown in Fig. 5(b) and (c), the calculated binding energies for Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) on SnP substrate are much larger than the values obtained on the graphene surface. It can be concluded that the Li-O bond formed between Li atom in Li2S n and O atom from PO3-OH in SnP is the reason for the strong interactions between Li2S n and SnP. The configurations of Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) clusters on SnP under the condition without vdW force are shown in Fig. S2 (supplementary material). Table S1 (supplementary material) displays the binding energies of Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) clusters on SnP (002) lattice plane calculated under the condition with and without vdW force. It can be found that the ratios of vdW force in the binding energies for Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) clusters on SnP (002) lattice plane decrease with increasing lithiation of Li2S n from Li2S8 to Li2S. This is more likely caused by the higher polarity of the short chain Li2S n (n = 1, 2) [46]. The results derived from the experiments and calculations both confirm the strong chemical interactions between Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) and SnP. The symmetrical cells were assembled to investigate the electrochemical reactions of Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) at SnP-G and graphene electrodes, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 6 (a), two pairs of redox current peaks can be observed from the CV curves obtained with the symmetrical cell using the SnP-G electrodes in a Li2S6-containning electrolyte. For the cathodic branch, the current peaks at −0.22 V and −0.82 V are attributed to the reduction of S8 to Li2S6 and further reduction of Li2S6 to Li2S on the working electrode. For the anodic branch, the peaks at 0.22 V and 0.82 V are due to the oxidization of Li2S to Li2S6 and further oxidation of Li2S6 to S8 [47]. While in Fig. 6(b), from the CV curves obtained with the cell prepared with the graphene electrodes, no current peak can be observed. Thus, it is clearly that the kinetics for the redox reactions of Li2S6 is facilitated on the SnP-G electrodes [48]. CV profiles obtained with the Li-S coin cells prepared with the SnP-G-S and G-S cathodes were measured respectively as shown in Fig. 6(c). Both cells show two typical reduction peaks at approximately 2.30 V and 2.00 V (vs Li+/Li), which correspond to the multi-step lithiation of sulfur in the discharge process [49]. The first current peak at around 2.30 V is attributed to the reduction of S8 to soluble high order long-chain Li2S n (4 ≤ n ≤ 8). The current peak at around 2.00 V is due to the further reduction of Li2S n (4 ≤ n ≤ 8) to the insoluble Li2S2 and Li2S [50]. As can be observed, the CV curve obtained with the cell fabricated with the G-S cathode shows the broadened and dwarf reduced current peak at 2.30 V and 1.96 V. While the cell with the SnP-G-S cathode announces sharp current peaks at more positive potential of 2.34 V and 2.02 V, respectively. What’s more, on the oxidation branch, the overlapped anodic current peaks for the oxidization of Li2S to polysulfide and sulfur can be observed at around 2.40 V [51]. Besides, the starting potential and the anodic current peak potential of the oxidation branch for the SnP-G-S cathode are all much negative than that obtained with the G-S cathode, which indicates the accelerated kinetics of conversion reactions for polysulfide on the SnP-G-S cathode [52]. Furthermore, the climbing-image nudged elastic band (ci-NEB) methods [53] were employed to reveal the energy barrier for Li2S decomposition (electrochemical oxidation) on the SnP. For the electrochemical oxidation of Li2S, the decomposition of Li2S involves the breaking of Li-S bond to yield a single Li ion. As shown in Fig. 6(d), the calculation results prove that the decomposition barrier for Li2S on the surface of SnP is 0.47 eV, which is significantly smaller than the value of 1.96 eV on the surface of graphene (Fig. S3, supplementary material). Thus, both the experimental and calculation results confirm the important roles that SnP plays in the accelerated electrochemical reduction and oxidation of polysulfide. Fig. 6(e) shows the EIS spectrum obtained with the Li-S cells fabricated with G-S and SnP-G-S cathodes, respectively. The corresponding equivalent circuit is displayed as the inset of Fig. 6(e). As listed in Table 1 , the parameters denoted as R 1, R SEI, R ct and W stand for the ohmic resistance, interfacial resistance, charge-transfer resistance and Warburg impedance, respectively. The charge-transfer resistance R ct for the Li-S cell with SnP-G-S cathode is 56.75 Ω, which is smaller than 87.04 Ω for the cell with G-S cathode, indicating the accelerated kinetics of redox reactions of polysulfide on the surface of SnP. The straight line in the low frequency regions of EIS spectrum is corresponding to the diffusion of Li ions which can be described as: (2) Z re = R 1 + R SEI + R ct + σ ω - 1 / 2 in which the value of σ is inversely proportional to the Li-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li + ) according to the formula: (3) D Li + = 0.5 RT / A n 2 F 2 C σ 2 Here, the parameters D, R, T, A, n, F, C and σ represent the diffusion coefficient, gas constant, absolute temperature, surface area of the electrode, the charge numbers of electrons involved in the reaction, Faraday constant, the concentration of Li+ and the Warburg factor. As listed in Table S2 (supplementary material), Li-ion diffusion coefficient in the SnP-G-S cathode is 3.1 × 10−10 cm2 s−1, which is larger than that of 6.6 × 10−11 cm2 s−1 for G-S electrode, indicating the enhanced transfer of Li ions in the SnP-G-S cathode. The similar phenomena have been reported by using the layered materials with larger interlamellar distance [16,27]. The visible Li-S cell is prepared with the SnP-G-S cathode and lithium foil in a visible container. The cell using the G-S cathode is prepared for contrast. Before discharging, the electrolyte in both cells was colorless as shown in Fig. 7 . After discharging 0.5 h at 0.2C, an obvious color change to yellow could be found especially nearby the cathode from the cell prepared with the G-S cathode (Fig. 7(a)). With the depth of discharge (DOD) increasing, the color of the electrolyte was darker and darker. The phenomenon demonstrates that the soluble polysulfides were generated during the discharge process and diffused from the G-S cathode to the electrolyte. On the contrast, as shown in Fig. 7(b), in the cell prepared with the SnP-G-S cathode, the electrolyte remained almost colorless from the beginning to the end of the discharge, demonstrating that the polysulfides were effectively anchored within the SnP-G-S cathode. The experiments as above-mentioned confirm again the roles of SnP in suppression the shuttle effect in Li-S cell. The rate performances of the SnP-G-S and G-S cathodes were measured at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 C. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the SnP-G-S cathode shows a discharge capacity of 1296.1 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C which is larger than 1089.1 mAh g−1 obtained with the G-S cathode, indicating the higher utilization of sulfur in the SnP-G-S cathode. The G-S cathode delivers capacities of 457.2, 354.0, 283.5 and 192.4 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 C, respectively, which is smaller than the values of 760.8, 661.2, 614.9 and 540.6 mAh g−1 obtained with the SnP-G-S cathode. With increasing the discharge rates, the specific capacities of G-S cathode decrease more sharply than that of the SnP-G-S cathode. Moreover, when the discharge rate returns to 0.1C, the capacity for the SnP-G-S cathode recovers to 672.6 mAh g−1, which is larger than 390.0 mAh g−1 for the G-S cathode. The above mentioned results indicate that due to the strong affinity of SnP towards polysulfides and the conductivity enhancement of graphene, the SnP-G composite plays an important role in accelerating electrochemical reduction and oxidation of sulfur and sulfide, and resulting in obvious enhancement of rate performance for Li-S cells. Besides, the contribution of SnP capacity in the SnP-G-S composite can be ignored because in the voltage range of 1.7–2.8 V, the specific capacity of SnP is less than 10 mAh g−1 (Fig. S4, supplementary material). Moreover, the SnP-G-S cathode exhibits stable cycling performance at 1.0 C as shown in Fig. 8(b). The initial discharge capacities of SnP-G-S and G-S cathodes at 1.0 C are 941.0 and 744.0 mAh g−1, respectively. The SnP-G-S cathode remains a specific capacity of 718.3 mAh g−1 after 250cycles. The capacity retention is calculated to be 76.3% and the capacity decay is about 0.095% per cycle. On the contrary, the specific capacity of G-S cathode is only 389.4 mAh g−1 after 250cycles, with capacity retention of 52.3% and capacity decay rate of 0.19% per cycle. Thus, the SnP-G-S cathode exhibits relatively better cycling stability than the G-S cathode. The long-term cycling performance of Li-S cell is shown in Fig. 8(c). It demonstrates that SnP-G-S materials have a superior cycling capability with an initial capacity of 984.0 mAh g−1 at 1.0 C. After the subsequent 800 cycles at 1.0 C, it remains a high specific capacity of 543.7 mAh g−1 with capacity retention of 55.3% and capacity fading rate of 0.056% per cycle. The good cycling capability of SnP-G-S cathode is reasonably attributed to the strong chemisorptions of SnP towards polysulfides and the accelerated conversion reactions of polysulfides which lead to the inhibition of the shuttle effect. The pouch type Li-S battery was fabricated by employing SnP-G-S cathodes. The controlled pouch type battery was assembled by using the conventional carbon–sulfur (C-S) composite cathodes. As shown in Fig. 9 , the cell with SnP-G-S cathodes exhibits an initial discharge capacity of 1266.6 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C. After 100 cycles, it remains a specific capacity of 973.7 mAh g−1, corresponding to capacity retention of 76.9%. While the conventional C-S cathodes also present a high initial capacity of 1176.7 mAh g−1 but poor capacity retention of 55.2% after 37 cycles at 0.1C. Meanwhile the coulombic efficiency for the charge–discharge cycle obtained with the pouch cell using SnP-G-S cathodes is above 99% for the first 40 cycles that is larger than 93%–95% for the pouch cell prepared with C-S cathodes. It can be concluded that the SnP-G-S materials are advanced for restraining the shuttle effect and improving the cycling performance possibly via a capture-accelerated conversion mechanism of polysulfide at the surface of SnP. In other words, during the discharge process, the dissolved polysulfides are captured by SnP through a relatively strong chemical interaction, and then are accelerated to electrochemically reduce to Li2S. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have demonstrated that the tin (IV) phosphate (Sn(HPO4)2·H2O, SnP) is a kind of novel dual-functional accelerators to realize the long-term and high specific energy Li-S batteries. The SnP is verified to possess strong chemisorption towards polysulfide and consequently accelerate the conversion reaction of polysulfide to sulfide. DFT calculations reveal that the Li-O bond formed between Li atom (from Li2S n , n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) and O atom (from PO3-OH in SnP) is the main reason for the strong interactions between Li2S n and SnP. Additionally, the energy barrier for lithium sulfide decomposition on SnP is proved to decrease significantly compared to that on graphene. Due to the above-mentioned advantages, the coin cell fabricated with the SnP-G-sulfur cathode maintains a stable cycling performance at 1.0 C over 800 cycles with an ultralow capacity decay of 0.056% per cycle. What’s more, the assembled pouch cell also exhibits a high initial discharge capacity of 1266.6 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and excellent cycle performance with capacity retention as high as 76.9% at 0.1C for 100cycles. The presented results indicate the usefulness of the dual-functional sulfur host and put insights on the accelerating mechanism of tin (IV) phosphate to polysulfide. coredata.dc:description: To anchor the polysulfide and enhance the conversion kinetics of polysulfide to disulfide / sulfide is critical for improving the performance of lithium-sulfur battery. For this purpose, the graphene-supported tin (IV) phosphate (Sn(HPO4)2·H2O, SnP) composites (SnP-G) are employed as the novel sulfur hosts in this work. When compared to the graphene-sulfur and carbon–sulfur composites, the SnP-G-sulfur composites exhibit much better cycling performance at 1.0C over 800cycles. Meanwhile, the pouch cell fabricated with the SnP-G-sulfur cathodes also exhibits excellent performance with an initial capacity of 1266.6 mAh g−1 (S) and capacity retention of 76.9% after 100cycles at 0.1C. The adsorption tests, density functional theory (DFT) calculations in combination with physical characterizations and electrochemical measurements provide insights into the mechanism of capture-accelerated conversion mechanism of polysulfide at the surface of SnP. DFT calculations indicate that the Li-O bond formed between Li atom (from Li2S n , n = 1, 2, 4, 6, 8) and O atom (from PO3-OH in SnP) is the main reason for the strong interactions between Li2S n and SnP. As a result, SnP can effectively restrain the shuttle effect and improving the cycling performance of Li-S cell. In addition, by employing the climbing-image nudged elastic band (ci-NEB) methods, the energy barrier for lithium sulfide decomposition (charging reaction) on SnP is proved to decrease significantly compared to that on graphene. It can be concluded that SnP is an effective sulfur hosts acting as dual-functional accelerators for the conversion reactions of polysulfide to sulfide (discharging reaction) as well as polysulfide to sulfur (charging reaction).
